tn.text: Luke begins to tell about the mission trips on which the church at Antioch send Barnabas and Saul.
Verse 1 gives background information about the people in the church at Antioch. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

Here the first word "they"  probably refers to these five leaders but may also include the other believers. The next words "they" and "their" probably refer to the other three leaders not including Barnabas and Saul but could include other believers.

tn.ref: Now in the church in Antioch
tn.text: "At that time in the church at Antioch"
(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: foster brother of Herod the tetrarch
tn.text: Manaen was probably Herod's playmate or close friend growing up.
ruler of a quarter or one fourth of the country
This word is used to mark two events that are happening at the same time.
"Appoint to serve me"
The verb here means that God chose them to do this work.

tn.ref: laid their hands on these men
tn.text: "laid their hands on these men whom God had set apart for his service." This act showed that the leaders agreed that the Holy Spirit had called Barnabas and Saul to do this work. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"sent those men off" or "sent those men off to do the work the Holy Spirit told them to do"
Here the words "they," "They," and "their" refer to Barnabas and Silas.
This word marks an event that happened because of a previous event. In this case, the previous event is Barnabas and Saul being set apart by the Holy Spirit.
The phrase "went down" is used here because Seleucia is lower in elevation than Antioch.
a city by the sea
The city of Salamis was on Cyprus Island.

Possible meanings are that 1) "there were multiple Jewish synagogues in the city of Salamis where Barnabas and Saul preached" or 2) "Barnabas and Saul started at the synagogue at Salamis and continued to preach in all the synagogues they found while they traveled around the Island of Cyprus."

tn.ref: They also had John Mark as their assistant
tn.text: "John Mark went with them and was helping them" (UDB)
"helper"
Here the word "they" refers to Paul, Silas, and John Mark.
The words "This man" refer to "Sergius Paulus." The first word "he" refers to Sergius Paulus, the proconsul; the second word "he" refers to Elymas (also called Bar-Jesus), the magician.
They crossed from one side of the island to the other and shared the gospel message in each town they passed through.
a major city on Cyprus island where the proconsul lived
Here "found" means they came upon him without looking for him. AT: "they met" (UDB) or "they came upon"
"a particular person who practices witchcraft" or "a person who practices supernatural magic arts"
"Bar Jesus" means "Son of Jesus." There is no relation between this man and Jesus Christ. Jesus was a common name at that time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"was often with" or "was often in the company of"
This was a governor in charge of a Roman province. AT: "governor"
This is background information about Sergius Paulus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This was Bar-Jesus, who was also called "the magician." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: that is how his name is translated
tn.text: "that was what he was called in Greek"

tn.ref: opposed them; he tried to turn
tn.text: "resisted them by trying to turn" or "attempted to stop them by trying to turn"

tn.ref: tried to turn the proconsul away from the faith
tn.text: "attempted to persuade the governor not to believe the gospel message"
While on the island of Paphos, Paul begins to talk to Elymas.
The words "him," "You," and "you" refer to the magician Elymas (also called Bar Jesus). (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:13:06|13:6-8]])

tn.ref: Saul, who is also called Paul
tn.text: "Saul" as his Jewish name, and "Paul" was his Roman name. Since he was speaking to a Roman official, he used his Roman name. AT: "Saul, who now called himself Paul" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"looked at him intensely"
Paul is saying the man is acting like the devil. AT: "You are like the devil" or "You act like the devil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you are full of all kinds of deceit and wickedness
tn.text: "you are always intent in causing others to believe what is not true using falsehood and always doing what is wrong"
In this context it means to be lazy and not diligent in following God's law.

tn.ref: You are an enemy of every kind of righteousness
tn.text: Paul is grouping Elymas with the devil. Just as the devil is an enemy of God and is against righteousness, so also was Elymas.

tn.ref: You will never stop twisting the straight paths of the Lord, will you?
tn.text: Paul uses this question to rebuke Elymas for opposing God. AT: "You are always saying that the truth about the Lord God is false!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: the straight paths of the Lord
tn.text: Here "straight paths" refer to the ways that are true. AT: "the true ways of the Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Paul finishes speaking to Elymas.
The words "you" and "him" refer to Elymas, the magician.
The word "he" refers to the Sergius Paulus, proconsul (governor of Paphos).

tn.ref: the hand of the Lord is upon you
tn.text: Here "hand' represents the power of God and "upon you" implies punishment. AT: "The Lord will punish you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will make you blind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: You will not see the sun
tn.text: Elymas will be so completely blind that he not even be able to see the sun. AT: "You will not even see the sun"
"for a period of time" or "until the time appointed by God"

tn.ref: there fell on Elymas a mist and darkness
tn.text: "the eyes of Elymas became blurry and then dark" or "Elymas started seeing unclearly and then he could not see anything"
"Elymas wandered around" or "Elymas started feeling around and"
This was a governor in charge of a Roman province. AT: "governor"
"he believed in Jesus"

tn.ref: he was astonished at the teaching about the Lord
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the teaching about the Lord amazed him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a new part of the story about Paul in Antioch in Pisidia.
Verses 13 and 14 give background information about this part of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

"Paul and his friends" were Barnabas and John Mark (also called John). From this point on, Saul is called Paul in Acts.  Paul's name is listed first which indicates that he had become the leader of the group. It is important to keep this order in the translation.
This marks the beginning of a new part of the story.
"traveled by sailboat from Paphos"
"arrived in Perga which is in Pamphylia"
"But John Mark left Paul and Barnabas"
"the city of Antioch in the district of Pisidia" (UDB)

tn.ref: After the reading of the law and the prophets
tn.text: The "law and the prophets" refer to parts of the Jewish scriptures which were read. AT: "After someone read from the books of the law and the writings of the prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"told someone to say" or "asked someone to say"
The term "brothers" is here used by the people in the synagogue to refer to Paul and Barnabas as fellow Jews.

tn.ref: if you have any message of encouragement
tn.text: "if you want to say anything to encourage us"
"please speak it" or "please tell it to us"
Paul begins his speech to those in the synagogue in Pisidian Antioch. He begins by talking about things that happened in Israel's history.
The first word "he" refers to Paul. The second word "he" refers to God.
Here the word "our" refers to Paul and his fellow Jews. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
The words "they" and "them" refer to the Israelites.
This could refer to moving his hands as a signal that he was ready to speak. AT: "moved his hands to show that he was about to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
This refers to Gentiles who had converted to Judaism. AT: "you who are not Israelites but who worship God."
"listen to me" or "listen to what I am about to say"

tn.ref: The God of this people Israel
tn.text: "The God the people of Israel worship"
"our Jewish ancestors"
"caused them to become very numerous" (UDB)
This refers to God's mighty power. AT: "with great power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"out from the land of Egypt"
This means "he tolerated them." Some versions have have a different word that means "he took care of them." AT: "God endured their disobedience" or "God took care of them"
Here the word "he" refers to God.
The words "their land" refer to the land the seven nations had previously occupied.
The words "our" and "them" refer to the people of Israel. Paul's Jewish audience is included in "our" as well as Paul and Barnabas. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
Here the word "nations" refers to different people groups and not to geographical boundaries.

tn.ref: took place over four hundred and fifty years
tn.text: "took more than 450 years to accomplish"
"until the time of the prophet Samuel"
The quotation here is from the history of Samuel and from a Psalm of Ethan in the Old Testament.
"to be their king for forty years"
This expression means God caused Saul to stop being king. AT: "rejected Saul from being king" (UDB)

tn.ref: he raised up David to be their king
tn.text: "God chose David to be their king." Here "raised up" is an idiom that means God caused David to become the king.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"the king of Israel" or "the king over the Israelites"

tn.ref: It was about David that God said
tn.text: "God said this about David"
"I have observed that"

tn.ref: to be a man after my heart
tn.text: This expression means he "is a man who wants what I want." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The quotation here is from the Gospels.
"From David's descendants." This is placed at the beginning of the sentence to emphasize that the savior had to be one of David's descendants. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:13:21|13:22]])
This refers to the people of Israel. AT: "gave to the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"just as God promised he would do"

You can translate the word  "repentance" as the verb "repent." AT: "the baptism to repent" or "the baptism that people requested when they wanted to repent for their sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: Who do you think I am?
tn.text: John asked this question to compel the people to think about who he was. AT: "Think about who I am" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
John was referring to the Messiah, whom they were expecting to come. AT: "I am not the Messiah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This emphasizes the importance of what he will say next.
This also refers to the Messiah. AT: "The Messiah will soon come" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: the shoes of whose feet I am not worthy to untie
tn.text: "I am not worthy even to untie his shoes." The Messiah is so much greater than John that he did not even feel worthy do the lowest job for him.
Here the word "us" includes Paul and his entire audience in the synagogue. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
The word "they" and "their" refers to the Jews who lived in Jerusalem.

tn.ref: Brothers, children of the line of Abraham ... who worship God
tn.text: Paul addresses his audience of Jews and Gentile converts to Judaism to remind them of their special status as worshiping the true God.

tn.ref: the message about this salvation has been sent
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God has sent the message about this salvation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "salvation" can be translated with the verb "save." AT: "that God will save people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"did not realize that this man Jesus was the one whom God had sent to save them" (UDB)
Here the word "sayings" represents the message of the prophets. AT: "the writings of the prophets" or "the message of the prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "which someone reads" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: they fulfilled sayings of the prophets
tn.text: "they actually did just what the prophets said they would do in the books of the prophets"
Here the word "they" refers to the Jewish people and their religious leaders in Jerusalem. The word him" here refers to Jesus.

tn.ref: they found no good cause for death
tn.text: "they did not find any reason why Jesus should be killed"
The word "asked" here is a strong word meaning to demand, beg or plead for.

tn.ref: When they had completed all the things that were written about him
tn.text: "When thy did to Jesus all the things that the prophets said would happen to him"

tn.ref: they took him down from the tree
tn.text: It may be helpful to explicitly say Jesus died before this happened. AT: "they killed Jesus and then took him down from the cross after he died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"from the cross." This was another way people at that time referred to the cross. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"But" indicates a strong contrast between what the people did and what God did.

tn.ref: raised him from the dead ones
tn.text: "raised him from the ones that were dead." To be with "the dead ones" means that Jesus was dead.
"made alive again"

tn.ref: He was seen ... Galilee to Jerusalem
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The disciples who traveled with Jesus from Galilee to Jerusalem saw him for many days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
We know from other writings that this period was 40 days. Translate "many days" with a term that would be appropriate for that length of time.

tn.ref: are now his witnesses to the people
tn.text: "are now testifying to the people about Jesus" or "are now telling the people about Jesus"
The second quotation here is from the prophet Isaiah.
This word marks an event that happened because of previous event. In this case, the previous event is God's raising Jesus from the dead.

"our ancestors." Paul is still speaking to the Jews and Gentile converts in the synagogue at Antioch of Pisidia. These were the physical ancestors of the Jews, and the spiritual ancestors of the converts.
"God has fulfilled these promises"

"to us, who are the children of our ancestors." Paul is still speaking to the Jews and Gentile converts in the synagogue at Antioch of Pisidia. These were the physical ancestors of the Jews, and the spiritual ancestors of the converts.

tn.ref: in that he raised up Jesus back to life
tn.text: "by making Jesus alive again"

tn.ref: This is also what was written in the second Psalm
tn.text: "This truth is also written in the second Psalm"
"Psalm 2"
These are important titles that describe the relationship between Jesus and God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

tn.ref: he raised him up from the dead ones so that his body will not return to decay, he has spoken like this
tn.text: "God spoke these words about his making Jesus alive again so that he would never die again"
The phrase "the dead ones" refers to the people who have died. To be raised from among them means to become alive again.
"certain blessings"

tn.ref: This is why he also says in another Psalm
tn.text: Paul's audience would have understood that this Psalm refers to the Messiah. AT: "In another Psalm of David, he also says about the Messiah" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"David also says." David is the author of Psalm 16 from which this quotation is taken.

tn.ref: You will not allow your Holy One to see decay
tn.text: The phrase "see decay" is a metonym for "decay." AT: "You will not allow the body of your Holy One to rot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
David is speaking to God here.
"during his lifetime"
"did what God wanted him to do" or "did what pleased God"
This was a polite way to refer to death. AT: "he died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"was buried with his ancestors who had died"
The phrase "saw decay" is a metonym for "his body decayed." AT: "his body rotted" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"but Jesus whom"
The phrase "saw no decay" is a way to say "did not decay." AT: "did not rot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the word "him" refers to Jesus.

tn.ref: let it be known to you
tn.text: "know this" or "this is important for you to know"
Paul uses this term because they are his fellow-Jews and followers of Judaism. They are not Christian believers at this point. AT: "my fellow Israelites and other friends" (UDB)

tn.ref: that through this man is proclaimed to you forgiveness of sins
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that we proclaim to you that your sins can be forgiven through Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The abstract noun "forgiveness" can be translated with the verb "to forgive." AT: "that God can forgive your sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: By him every one who believes
tn.text: "By him every person who believes" or "Every one who believes in him"

tn.ref: By him every one who believes is justified
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Jesus justifies everyone who believes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"all the sins"
Paul finishes his speech in the synagogue in Pisidian Antioch, which he began in [[:en:bible:notes:act:13:16|13:16]].
In his message to the people in the synagogue, Paul quotes the prophet Habakkuk.
Here the word "I" refers to God.
It is implied that the thing they should be careful about is Paul's message. AT: "give close attention to the things I have said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: that the thing the prophets spoke about
tn.text: "so that what the prophets spoke about"
"you who feel contempt" or "you who ridicule"
"be amazed" or "be shocked"
"then die"
"am doing something" or "am doing a deed"
"during your lifetime"
"I am doing something which"

tn.ref: even if someone announces it to you
tn.text: "even if someone tells you about it"
"When Paul and Barnabas were leaving"
"begged them to"
Here "words" refers to the message that Paul had spoken. AT: "this same message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Possible meanings are 1) this restates "As Paul and Barnabas left" in verse 42 or 2) Paul and Barnabas left the meeting before it ended and this occurs later.
These were non-Jewish people who converted to Judaism.

tn.ref: who spoke to them and urged them
tn.text: "and Paul and Barnabas spoke to those people and urged them"

tn.ref: to continue in the grace of God
tn.text: It is implied that they believed Paul's message that Jesus was the Messiah. AT: "to continue to trust that God kindly forgives people's sins because of what Jesus did" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here the word "him" refers to Paul.

The "city" represents the people in the city. This phrase is used to show the great response to the Lord's word. AT: "a large part of the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: to hear the word of the Lord
tn.text: It is implied that Paul and Barnabas were the ones who spoke the word of the Lord. AT: "to hear Paul and Barnabas speak about the Lord Jesus" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "Jews" represents Jewish leaders. AT: "the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here jealousy is spoken of as if it were something that could fill up a person. AT: "became very jealous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"contradicted" or "opposed"

tn.ref: the things that were said by Paul
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the things that Paul said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The first two instances of the word "you" are plural and refer to the Jews to whom Paul is speaking.
Here the word "we" refers to Paul and Barnabas but not the crowd that was present. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

Paul's quotation is from the prophet Isaiah in the Old Testament. In the original passage, the word "I" refers to God and the word "you" is singular and refers to the Messiah. Here, Paul and Barnabas seem to be saying that the quotation also refers to their ministry.
This implies that God had commanded this be done. AT: "God commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: that the word of God should first be spoken to you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that we speak the word of God to you first" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Seeing you push it away from yourselves
tn.text: Their rejection of the word of God is spoken of as if it were something they pushed away. AT: "Since you reject the word of God"

tn.ref: consider yourselves unworthy of eternal life
tn.text: "have shown that you are not worthy of eternal life" (UDB) or "act as though you are not worthy of eternal life"

tn.ref: we will turn to the Gentiles
tn.text: Here "turn" refers to a change in to whom they would teach. AT: "we will now tell the message to the Gentiles"
Here the truth about Jesus that Paul was preaching is spoken of as if it were a light that allowed people to see. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: bring salvation to the uttermost parts of the earth
tn.text: The abstract word "salvation" can be translated with the verb "to save." The phrase "uttermost parts" refers to everywhere. AT: "tell people everywhere in the world that I want to save them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: praised the word of the Lord
tn.text: Here "word" refers to the message about Jesus that they had believed. AT: "praised God for the message about the Lord Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: As many as were appointed to eternal life
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "As many as God appointed to eternal life believed" or "All the people whom God had chosen to receive eternal life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The word of the Lord was spread out through the whole region
tn.text: Here "word" refers to the message about Jesus. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Those who believed spread the word of the Lord through the whole region" or "Those who believed went everywhere in the region and told others about the message of Jesus"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This ends Paul and Barnabas' time in Antioch of Pisidia and they go to Iconium.
Here the word "they" refers to Paul and Barnabas.
This probably refers to the leaders of the Jews. AT: "the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"convinced" or "stirred up"
"the most important men"

tn.ref: These stirred up a persecution against Paul and Barnabas
tn.text: "They convinced the important men and women to persecute Paul and Barnabas"

tn.ref: threw them out beyond the border of their city
tn.text: "removed Paul and Barnabas from their city"

tn.ref: shook off the dust from their feet against them
tn.text: This was a symbolic act to indicate to the unbelieving people that God had rejected them and would punish them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])
This probably refers to the new believers in the Antioch of Pisidia that Paul and Silas just left.
